Corresponding authors at: Department of Physical Chemistry, Kazan Federal University, Kazan 420008, Russia Department of Physical Chemistry, Kazan Federal University Kazan 420008 Russia The oxidation and catalytic oxidation products of pyrene was analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The in-situ transformation of Cu-based catalysts was analyzed. A qualitative model of pyrene oxidation with and without catalyst was built. CuO nanoparticles were in-situ formed as the active phases, and they decreased the polymerization and condensation of pyrene. The oxidation pathways of pyrene with and without CuO nanoparticles with the main product of 9-oxo-phenaleno-1-carbaldehyde were considered, which includes two elementary stages with the limiting Gibbs energy barrier of 227 kJ/mol. CuO increases the number of stages to three and reduces the Gibbs activation energy by 20 % of the limiting stage of pyrene oxidation. These findings provide new insights into the initial oxidation of pyrene and its catalysis. The proposed model and methods using Density functional theory (DFT) calculation offer a new theoretical approach for investigating hydrocarbon oxidation as well as designing catalytic systems for accelerating their oxidation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Quantum calculation DFT study Reaction pathway Catalytic hydrocarbon oxidation Pyrene 1 Introduction Oil occupies a leading position among energy resources and is the most important raw material used in the chemical industries. The rapid growth of the industries using oils as fuel or precursors for chemistry together with the depletion of conventional light oil reserves increases the importance of the efficient development of heavy oil reserves [1]. Heavy oil, which has a high viscosity and density, holds about 60–70% of total world’s oil reserves and is practically not developed in comparison to conventional oils [2,3]. The poor physical properties (viscosity and density) of heavy oils make them much more difficult to be extracted from the reservoirs by traditional methods (like water injection), which initiates active research in the development of thermal methods, such as steam injection and in-situ combustion (ISC) technology. ISC is a promising technology for recovering heavy oil and bitumen [4]. The essence of the technology lies in triggering a cascade of exothermic oxidation reactions in oil-containing reservoirs, and establishing a combustion front to reduce viscosity and displace oil towards producers [5]. However, the unstable combustion front in reservoirs is a serious hindrance to the wide application of ISC technology [6]. To improve the performance of heavy oil combustion, using catalysts is necessary [7]. For designing efficient catalysts, it is important to understand heavy oil oxidation process at the molecular level. The multicomponent nature of oil greatly complicates the study of the already complex multi-stage processes occurring during combustion. Therefore, even though many studies have been performed to study crude oil oxidation, its oxidation mechanism remains unclear. Heavy oil usually can be separated into saturate, aromatic, resin, asphaltene (SARA) fractions. Asphaltene, which consists of a lot condensed aromatic hydrocarbons, is the main fraction to sustain stable combustion front [8]. However, asphaltene still has a too complicated composition to be used for theoretical calculation. Therefore, a common approach is to choose a model compound that reflects the chemical properties of a whole class of similar compounds neglecting the effects of additivity and synergy associated with the presence of other components. The condensed polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) pyrene can be usually considered as a basic structural unit or condensed nuclei of asphaltenes [9]. Moreover, as is well known, molecular modeling is a compromise between accuracy and computational cost, therefore, in this case, the simplest representative of condensed aromatic hydrocarbons was chosen for calculations. Therefore, in this work, pyrene was chosen as a model oil component. Hydrocarbon oxidation mechanisms are actively studied using various methods, both theoretical and experimental approaches [10–16]. Conde et al. [17] and Bezalel et al. [18] studied the oxidation processes of pyrene experimentally in reactors as well as in living organisms during the metabolism studying, and obtained products were similar. The sequential oxidation of molecular polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons up to CO have been simulated, however, atomic oxygen was used as a reagent [19]. In references [20–22], attempts to simulate the processes of oxidation of the pyrenyl radical by molecular oxygen have been performed at high temperatures (above 1000 K) exceeding the temperatures of ISC (500–1000 K [23]) without taking into consideration the effect of surrounding medium, which can significantly change the activation energies due to the stabilization of transition states [24,25]. Here, we systematically examined the oxidation process of pure pyrene in so-called low-temperature oxidation (LTO) in the temperature range of 473–623 K and the pressure of 50 bar using both experimental and calculation approaches. The role of a catalyst in the ISC process, on the one hand, is to reduce the combustion temperature and sustain a stable combustion front, on the other hand, control the resulting products. Thus, the efficiency of a catalyst can be assessed by two criteria: reduction of reaction activation barriers and selectivity for the desired products. Various substances are used as catalytic systems, such as metallic salts and oxides of transition metals [3,26–30], metal complexes, dispersed pure metal particles [31], organic compounds, natural minerals, and clays [32]. Unfortunately, the nature of their activity is often unclear. To increase efficiency in oil environment, a catalyst should be well dispersed in reaction medium. Previously, oil-dispersed copper (II) stearate was considered as a catalyst in our group for catalyzing heavy oil oxidation, and a high catalytic performance was obtained. Thus, copper (II) stearate was chosen as oil-dispersed catalysts in this work. For studying oxidation mechanism, the selected compound with and without a catalyst is placed in an autoclave where conditions that are close to those of ISC are simulated, followed by an analysis of the resulting products. Therefore, it is possible to determine the efficiency of a catalyst by comparing its behavior with and without a catalyst. With this approach, along with the experimental study, one can also apply the methods of molecular modeling to gain a deeper knowledge of the processes involved. For oil-dispersed catalysts, the in-situ transformation is also very important. We also studied the thermal decomposition of copper (II) stearate at autoclave conditions, and concluded that the active phase is copper (II) oxide with which further simulations were performed. Many researchers have been using molecular modeling in the processes of simulating catalytic reactions to determine the activity of a catalyst and to interpret experimental data [15,16,33–38]. Based on simulation in silico, it is possible to study in detail the influence of various factors on oxidation processes at the molecular level: influence of a medium, establishing the role of the presence of other molecules, evaluating the influence of intermolecular interactions, and finding the most probable reaction centers, etc., which is an important step towards the design of catalytic systems for ISC. 2 Materials and methodology In this work, pyrene was purchased from ACROS ORGANICS, with 98 % purity, and used without purification. Copper (II) stearate was purchased from Shanghai Reagent Company. A 300 ml stainless steel autoclave reactor with a special quartz cell inside was used for pyrene oxidation experiments. The sample mass was 2 g. Initial experimental pressure was 50 bar created by air injection. The reactor was heated to the required temperature at a heating rate of 5 K/min. The mass concentration of catalyst was 0.1 wt% (Cu accounts for the total sample mass). After reaching the required temperature, the experiment was stopped and autoclave was cooled down immediately to room temperature. After experiments, the obtained products were separated into soluble and insoluble parts using CH2Cl2 and iso-C3H8OH as solvents. An Agilent 6890 N/5973 quadrupole gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) were used to analyze pyrene oxidation products. Time-of-flight mass spectrometer with matrix-activated laser desorption-ionization (MALDI-TOF MS) was employed to determine the molecular weight of pyrene oxidation products. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to study the crystal structure of the decomposition products of catalysts after experiments in the autoclave using a diffractometer MD-10 (Rodikon, St. Petersburg, Russia) with a position-sensitive detector for Fe-Kα radiation (λ = 1.93728 ◦A). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Merlin Carl Zeiss) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (Aztec, Oxford instruments) with 5 kV accelerating voltage was used to get the images of the catalyst surface. In addition, the possibility of pyrene to form radicals at experimental temperatures was also studied. For this purpose, pyrene was loaded in the autoclave and heated for an hour at 298, 353, 413, and 453 K, and then the system was cooled down to room temperature and the samples were analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). A microwave X-band (9.41 GHz, 2.0 mW) coupled with a magnetic field sweep at room temperature was employed in conjunction with a Bruker E500 spectrometer to obtain the EPR spectra. 3 Computational details The thermodynamic properties were calculated by ab initio in Gaussian 09 Rev. B.01 [22] with the combination of hybrid B3LYP functional and 6–311 G(d,p) basis set without vibrational frequency scaling factor because at the chosen level of theory the errors do not exceed 1 kJ/mol and are less than typical errors of ab initio computations [39]. The optimization of all structures was performed starting from different initial geometries to bypass a local minimum, and the optimized structure with minimal total electronic energy was selected for further analysis. The transition states characterized by one imaginary vibration frequency were localized using the Berny algorithm implemented in Gaussian program package. Searching the transition states of the structures of catalysts (copper (II) stearate or CuO surface) and optimization were performed using B3LYP/6–311 G(d,p) level of theory as well as the semi-empirical method PM6 with the further calculation of thermochemistry at B3LYP/6–311 G(d,p) as single-point. The differences in the Gibbs activation energies of elementary reactions for the two calculation schemes did not exceed 10% which is an acceptable error for the effects considered here. Structures containing the copper (II) oxide surface that require a significant computational cost were simulated using only the semi-empirical method PM6, and the thermochemistry was clarified for these structures as single-point at B3LYP/6–311 G(d,p) level of theory. The CuO surface was simulated as a slab containing 8 elementary cells (two in z direction, and four along x axis) that corresponds to 32 oxygen atoms and 32 copper atoms. The positions of CuO atoms were fixed during the simulation. The thickness was 3.4 Å. The crystal structure of CuO was taken from X-ray structural analysis [40], and the plane with (010) Miller indices was chosen. The surface area of the selected fragment of the crystal structure of CuO exceeded the dimensions of the pyrene molecule by almost 3 times, which was placed in the center of this substrate, excluding the role of edge effects. The IEFPCM polarizable continuum model [41] was used to take into account a solvation effect. The thermodynamic quantities for a sorption process were calculated by the supermolecule approach according to Eq. 1, where ∆ E is enthalpy ( ∆ H ) , Gibbs energy ( ∆ G ), or excess entropy ( ∆ S ) of intermolecular interaction; E AB , E A , and E B are energies of intermolecular complex and components. Basis set superposition error (BSSE) was estimated using the Boys and Bernardi method [42]. (1) ∆ E = E AB − E A + E B According to the transition state theory, the rate constant of a reaction is related to the Gibbs activation barrier by the Eyring-Polanyi equation (Eq. 2). (2) k = χ k b × T h e − ∆ G ≠ RT where k – the rate constant (с−1), χ – the transmission coefficient (in this case equal to 1), k b – the Boltzmann's constant being equal to 1.38 × 10−23 J/К, T – absolute temperature (К), h – the Planck's constant being equal to 6.62 × 10−34 J×s, R – the gas constant being equal to 8.314 J/mol × К, and ∆ G ≠ – the activation Gibbs energy (kJ/mol). The activation Gibbs energy is the difference between the energies of the transition state and the reactants. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Autoclave oxidation of pyrene with and without copper (II) stearate The temperature regime in autoclave experiments was chosen in such a way that the melting temperature of pyrene (Tm = 418–421 K [43]) was reached, but not boiling point (Tb = 677 K [44]). Insoluble and soluble in CH2Cl2 parts were observed after the heating of pyrene in autoclave. The insoluble reaction products contained coke. The soluble part was analyzed using MALDI-TOF technique ( Fig. 1b), and high molecular weight compounds with masses of about 400, 600, and 800 a.u. were observed, which corresponds to two, three, and four condensed pyrene fragments, respectively. Coking process usually combining cracking reactions, polymerization, and condensation. The existence of a large amount of free radicals can intensify polymerization, followed by the condensation reaction of aromatic rings to form large aromatic cores [45]. Thus, the coke formation may be associated with the polymerization of pyrene through the formation of free radicals. When pyrene is heated to 413 K, free radicals were formed as evidenced by EPR data ( Fig. 2). The EPR signal continues to increase with increasing temperature, which indicates an increase in the concentration of free radicals. Further, previous studies have shown that the concentration of stable free radicals increases with heating in coal and fossil fuel samples up to 500 °C due to the presence of extended aromatic systems, so it is not recommended to conduct EPR experiments at higher temperatures [46,47]. Note that the free radicals of pyrene remained for a long time, allowing their detection after the sample cooled to room temperature. In our experiments, we observed the pyrenyl radicals under heating. We can assume that these high-molecular compounds were formed as a result of reactions in which the pyrene radicals are recombined. The insoluble part also contains oxidized products, as indicated by the presence of a peak at 1740 cm−1 of the carbonyl group vibrational according FTIR spectrum (Fig. 1a). This large amount of compounds contain carbonyl group can be attributed to the presence of high oxidized and polymerized structures based on pyrene. These high molecular compounds are not soluble in solvents. It is difficult to analyze the obtained products by GC-MS due to their insolubility in common organic solvents. Nevertheless, we managed to analyze some products from the soluble part, which will be discussed in the later part with reaction pathway. The addition of copper (II) stearate significantly reduced the formation of products with a molecular weight above 400 a.u. according to the mass spectrum presented in Fig. 1d. One plausible explanation for this phenomenon can be due to the radical-scavenging ability of Cu(II) complex before its fully decomposition. The interaction of Cu(II) complex with produced radicals from pyrene through radical-based mechanism inhibit their further polymerization reactions to form larger molecules [48]. Further analysis of the insoluble precipitate by FTIR also showed the appearance of the peak at 1740 and 1200 cm−1 region corresponding to the carbonyl group CO vibrations and stretching vibrations of C-O bond, respectively (Fig. 1c). Based on thermogravimetry for copper based catalysts, the decomposition process begins at about 420 K; thus, under experimental conditions, copper (II) stearate itself can undergo thermal decomposition [3]. The decomposition of copper (II) stearate can lead to the formation of copper oxides. XRD spectra indicate that copper (II) oxide was formed in the autoclave ( Fig. 3a). Further analysis by SEM shows the formation of spherical CuO nanoparticles with the size of 20–60 nm (Fig. 3b). Our study suggests that CuO nanoparticles play the role of catalyst during the low temperature oxidation process of pyrene. According to the obtained experimental data, we can deduce that along with oxidation, polymerization processes also occur with the participation of pyrenyl. Therefore, alongside the oxidation of molecular pyrene, pyrenyl also needs to be considered. During the autoclave experiment, copper (II) stearate decomposed to copper oxide nanoparticles, which act as catalysts. The effect of the catalysts can be seen from the change in the selectivity of the reactions. Modeling molecular processes allows us to test hypotheses and shed light on ongoing processes. 4.2 Reaction pathways of the oxidation of pyrene with and without copper (II) stearate We have considered possible pathways for pyrene oxidation by molecular oxygen in the absence of the catalyst and on the copper (II) oxide surface. Both the oxidation reactions of pyrene and pyrenyl were considered. Pyrene and pyrenyl structures were optimized at B3LYP/6–311 G(d,p) level of theory. The radical center in pyrene was located at the edge carbon atom according data obtained by Semenikhin et al. [49] ( Fig. 4). The selected functional and basis set well reproduce the bond lengths in pyrene molecule (Fig. S1 in SI), which compares bond lengths and bond angles with experimental data obtained using X-ray diffractometer [50]. The error does not exceed 1 % for lengths and 0.7 % for angles, respectively. As a benchmark for the selected level of theory, the enthalpy for forming the complex between benzene and oxygen molecule was calculated. The calculated value 4.2 kJ/mol is in good agreement with the obtained experimental value 5.0 ± 1.3 kJ/mol for benzene-O2 complex [51]. Thus, the chosen level of theory reproduces with a sufficient accuracy in both the geometric parameters of the compounds and the energy of intermolecular interactions between the components. The pathways of the oxidation reaction of the pyrenyl radical through the formation of the phenanthryl radical were considered according the scheme proposed by Raj et al. [21] taking into account implicit solvation and conditions in autoclave experiments (T = 300 °C, P = 50 bar). Implicit solvation was added within the polarizable continuum model with the dielectric constant of pyrene ε = 3.14 [52]. The estimated value of the solvation energy of pyrene in pyrene using IEFPCM solvation model was − 12.1 kJ/mol, which is in good agreement with the values known from the [53] (from −10 to −14 kJ/mol). Sequential oxidation of pyrenyl with activation barriers and transition state structure is shown in Fig. 5. The addition of an oxygen molecule to pyrenyl proceeds without barrier, as does the stage of elimination of one oxygen atom from the product designated as P4_1. The limiting stage in the pyrenyl oxidation is the reorganization of 6-membered to 5-membered cycle (P2 to P3, Fig. 4) with the activation energy of 268 kJ/mol. The result of a complex of sequential and parallel chemical reactions was the formation of phenanthrene radicals. At the same time, the considered sequence reaction pathway of pyrene including fewer stages leads to a phenalene core (Fig. 4). To draw a conclusion about the predominant mechanism of oxidation on the basis of these calculations, it is necessary to choose a criterion for assessing the favorableness of one or another reaction pathway. The favorability of a particular reaction was evaluated in terms of kinetic and thermodynamic control. Kinetic reaction control is when the ratio of products is determined by the rate of the formation of products, and not by the relative stability of the products with respect to the reactants, as is the case with thermodynamic control. In accordance with the transition state theory for an elementary stage of a chemical reaction, the rate constant of a chemical reaction is related to the activation barrier by the Eyring-Polany equation, see Eq. 2. Thus, a quantitative measure of the favorableness of a chemical reaction is the activation Gibbs energy barrier (ΔG‡) in the case of kinetic control. The difference of the Gibbs energies between products and reagents (ΔGr, see Eq. 1) is the thermodynamic favorableness of a chemical reaction. The limited Gibbs energy activation barriers for the oxidation of pyrenyl by molecular oxygen is 268 kJ/mol, which, in accordance with Eq. 2, corresponds to the reaction rate constant 4.42 × 10−12 s−1 at 573 K. For 2 h of autoclave pyrene oxidation, at such a low-rate constant only a small part of pyrene undergoes conversion. Thus, it can be assumed that, under experimental conditions, the favorableness of one or another reaction is mainly determined by kinetic control. Following this criterion, we analyzed the pyrene conversion and chose the most probable reaction pathway presented in Fig. 5. In the most stable pyrene-oxygen complex the oxygen molecule was located close to center of pyrene molecule at a distance of 3 Å. The molecular complex of the oxygen molecule with pyrene undergoes a further transformation with the formation of surface peroxide (Fig. 5). The negative Gibbs energy of the reaction ΔGr < 0 was observed only in cases where oxygen was attached with two adjacent carbon atoms at the edge of the pyrene molecule. The most favorable product in terms of thermodynamic control (ΔG ‡ = 179 kJ / mol, ΔGr = −92 kJ / mol) was 4,5-peroxide (E_P1). At the same time, according to kinetic control, the smallest energy barrier (ΔG ‡ = 71 kJ/mol, ΔGr = 2 kJ/mol) had the pathway corresponding to the formation of 1,3а-peroxo-pyrene (A_P1 in Fig. 5). Fig. 5 presents a diagram with the different pathways of pyrene oxidation as a continuation of the peroxide formation. The formation of the A_P2_a compound is the most preferred pathway with the smallest barrier according to the kinetic control, as is highlighted by the yellow curve. This sequence of elementary stages will be taken into account for further discussions. More detailed data about thermodynamic values are shown in Figs. S2-S8 in SI. Thus, based on our modeling, the most likely oxidation product was 9-oxo-phenaleno-1-carbaldehyde (A_P2_a in Fig. 6). Elimination of a proton from A_P2_a from the formyl group produces the radical of A_P2_a which then is cyclized to form a 5-membered ring. The considered cyclization process (see Fig. 6) has a low activation barrier 83 kJ/mol. The process, in this case, was considered without the presence of a proton acceptor, which leads to an extremely thermodynamically unfavorable energy value of 655 kJ/mol. However, taking into account that both the oxidized compounds formed and the water formed in the system (proton Gibbs hydration energy −1064 kJ/mol [53]) can act as a proton acceptor, thermodynamic obstacles are easily eliminated. Thus, the cyclization reaction has an activation barrier less than in the previous stages and is not limiting. Therefore, it allows us to consider this pathway as the possible mechanism of pyrene oxidation under given conditions in the autoclave. This pathway has 2 stages according to calculations. The first one is the formation of peroxide with an energy barrier of 71 kJ/mol, and the second stage is the elimination of the acetylene molecule (ΔG ‡ = 227 kJ/mol) with the formation of the final product. The results obtained within the single pyrene molecule (dominant oxidation pathways) can be extrapolated to processes in condensed structures. Since the most likely reaction is the oxidation of pyrene to 9-oxo-phenaleno-1-carbaldehyde (A_P2_a in Fig. 5), the influence of the catalyst was found for this pathway. We speculate that the efficiency of the catalyst can be determined at the stage of the sorption of the substrate on its surface. Changes in the electronic structure of the adsorbed substrate compared to the non-adsorbed state result in changes in the geometric structure of the sorbate, consequently weakening some bonds. Weakened chemical bonds are excellent targets for being attacked by oxygen, which suggests both the reaction path and a rough estimate of the effectiveness of the catalyst. Let us illustrate this idea by the example of the established pathway for pyrene oxidation. Despite the fact that, as a result of heating under experimental conditions, copper (II) stearate decomposes to copper (II) oxide which probably plays the role of a catalyst, let us consider the sorption of pyrene on the surface of copper (II) stearate. Its structure was reproduced based on the following results [54,55] for the hexanoate complex, under the assumption that the length of the alkyl chain does not influence on geometry and activity of the central ion and its closest surrounding. The optimized structure, as well as a comparison with experimental data, is presented in Fig. S8 of SI. During comparing the optimized structure with experimental data [54,55], it was found that the chosen calculation method reproduces the geometry of the complex with a sufficiently high accuracy. The error in bond lengths and bond angles does not exceed 3 % and 3.5 %, respectively. It has been established by the methods of quantum-chemical modeling that the pyrene molecule is oriented near the complex, occupying one of the axial positions of the coordination sphere of the copper ion (Cu2+), at a distance of about 2.5 Å, which is typical for nonspecific interactions. The association energy is 26.8 kJ/mol. It is important to note that the mentioned energy value refers to the transfer of the model pyrene molecule from the vacuum to the associate. If additionally considering the energy required to extract the molecule of the model compound from the medium in which it is located (for example, a pyrene melt and the energy of pyrene solvation in pyrene), the association energies become either slightly higher than RT (ca. 2.5 kJ/mol), or positive, and the association will be thermodynamically unfavorable. With such a weak interaction between the components in the associate, one should not expect serious changes in the geometric parameters and the electron density distribution. Changes for all systems do not exceed 2 %, 4 %, and 4 % in bond lengths, angles, and charges on atoms, respectively. It was assumed that sorption (in the case of heterogeneous catalysis) or association (in the case of homogeneous catalysis) is the first stage of the catalytic process and the catalytic efficiency depends on the ability of the catalyst to influence the strength of some bonds in the substrate molecule. With such weak changes in pyrene molecules, it is not necessary to expect that the copper (II) stearate complex will exhibit high catalytic activity. In ternary systems that additionally include an oxygen molecule being located above the model compound, the sorption energy of an oxygen molecule on the associate consisting of a stearate complex and pyrene is also low and does not exceed 6 kJ/mol. The change in the length of the oxygen-oxygen bond as a result of sorption for the considered system is less than 2 %. The adsorption stage of pyrene on the copper (II) oxide slab has been accompanied by serious changes in the sorbate structure. Thus, the bond lengths between the carbon atoms of pyrene (and its oxidation products) and the oxygen atoms of the surface are approximately 1.45 angstroms, which suggests the covalent nature of the interaction. It implies large values of the sorption energies. It can be assumed that such changes in the structure of initial sorbate can result in decreasing coke formation in the catalyst containing system, because carbon atoms are less connected with each other due to high binding with CuO surface. It should be noted that the calculation method reproduces the energies of Cu-O and C-O bonds with an error of less than 9 % [56]. High sorption energies are also observed by other authors, for example, the sorption of pyrene and other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons on the surface of Rh, Pt, Pd, Ni was estimated at values reaching up to 900 kJ/mol [57]. The study on pyrene oxidation in the presence of copper-containing systems by the quantum-chemical modeling was carried out based on the dominant reaction path according to calculations and experimental data. It is well known that the molecular modeling methods balance between computational cost and accuracy. Because of the complicated system containing a lot of heavy atoms, it was decided to perform calculations in PM6 approach. The benchmarking with the PM6 and B3LYP methods was made before, which shows that both methods gave similar values in the energy barriers of the elementary stages of pure pyrene oxidation processes. As can be seen in Fig. 7 the differences in activation energy values in the case of the non-catalytic pyrene oxidation dominant pathway are less than 15 kJ/mol. And it was suggested that if the benefit of the addition of catalyst would be higher than this value, the catalytic activity would be approved. In the presence of CuO substrate (Fig. 7), the number of elementary stages increases from 2 to 3, without taking the sorption of reagents and desorption of products into consideration. The first stage is the cleavage of a bond between two carbon atoms, one of which is associated with oxygen, followed by the cleavage of the peroxide bond and the formation, as a consequence, of an aldehyde and epoxy fragment (ΔG‡ = 178 kJ/mol). Then, with a barrier of 47 kJ/mol, the C-C bond is destroyed in the epoxy group and the oxygen atom is incorporated between carbon atoms. The final stage is the cleavage of the C-O bond (ΔG‡ = 172 kJ/mol) in such a way that the oxygen atom remains in the oxidized product. The separated fragment is also bound with the substrate. Comparing the processes occurring in the absence and presence of a copper-based catalyst, it can be noticed that the largest barrier in the case of pure pyrene oxidation was 227 kJ/mol, while the maximum activation energy on the substrate was 178 kJ/mol, which is 21 % lower. As a result of modeling, it was found that copper (II) oxide has a catalytic effect on the oxidation of pyrene which correlates with experimental data. Comparison of the available experimental and calculated data suggests that the given model adequately reflects the oxidation process. 5 Conclusion In summary, it was experimentally determined that pure pyrene oxidation by oxygen leads to the formation of both low and high molecular weight products. The addition of copper (II) stearate significantly reduces the formation of high molecular weight products, while the copper (II) stearate itself undergoes thermal decomposition to copper (II) oxide nanoparticles at the autoclave conditions (T = 573 K, P = 50 bar). The dominant oxidized product with and without catalyst was 9-oxo-phenaleno-1-carbaldehyde. Based on our simulations, it was found that the formed copper (II) oxide nanoparticles but not stearates play the catalyst role for pyrene oxidation. The most probable reaction pathway of pure pyrene oxidation regulated by kinetic control and leading to the formation of 9-oxo-phenaleno-1-carbaldehyde was proposed. The oxidation pathway of pure pyrene included two elementary stages with the limiting Gibbs energy barrier of 227 kJ/mol. Copper (II) oxide increases the number of stages to three and reduces the limiting Gibbs energy barrier by 20%. The proposed quality model adequately described the pyrene oxidation with and without the catalyst in autoclave experiments. These new insights in the initial oxidation of pyrene and its catalysis not only helps to understand the combustion mechanism of asphaltene-like heavy oil component in in-situ combustion heavy oil recovery process, but also provides basis theoretical basis for the combustion of condensed polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). The proposed model and methods using quantum-mechanical DFT calculation offer a valuable, supplemental theoretical calculation approach for studying hydrocarbon oxidation and designing catalytic systems for accelerating the oxidation process. coredata.dc:description: The oxidation and catalytic oxidation products of pyrene was analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The in-situ transformation of Cu-based catalysts was analyzed. A qualitative model of pyrene oxidation with and without catalyst was built. CuO nanoparticles were in-situ formed as the active phases, and they decreased the polymerization and condensation of pyrene. The oxidation pathways of pyrene with and without CuO nanoparticles with the main product of 9-oxo-phenaleno-1-carbaldehyde were considered, which includes two elementary stages with the limiting Gibbs energy barrier of 227 kJ/mol. CuO increases the number of stages to three and reduces the Gibbs activation energy by 20 % of the limiting stage of pyrene oxidation. These findings provide new insights into the initial oxidation of pyrene and its catalysis. The proposed model and methods using Density functional theory (DFT) calculation offer a new theoretical approach for investigating hydrocarbon oxidation as well as designing catalytic systems for accelerating their oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: New insights of the initial processes of pyrene oxidation in the presence of Cu-based catalysts: Quantum-mechanical calculation and experimental evidence
